title: About Me
text: Hi there, I’m Ananya. I’m passionate about analyzing data for social good and making knowledge from research more accessible. I’ve always enjoyed stories from a young age and I believe that data can tell really meaningful ones. I recently got my Bachelor’s in Psychology, and I decided to switch fields a bit because I wanted to understand the research process better and learn more about big data analysis. In past internships, I’ve collected and analyzed survey data related to the psychosocial impact of COVID-19 and how a social media app can improve relationship quality. I was involved in a lot of teamwork since big surveys are a team effort and I’ve also interacted with several people while administering the surveys. Through these experiences, I realized that research needs to be inclusive and representative - and that’s what I want to work towards. Along the way I’ve also learnt programming languages like R, Python, Java, and SQL. I’m currently a graduate student at the Data Analytics and Computational Social Science program at UMass Amherst - where I’m able to combine all of my interests.

title: About Me
text:
Education/Work Background
I’m currently a graduate student at the Data Analytics and Computational Social Science program at the University of Massachusetts Amherst. Before this, I earned my Bachelor of Arts degree in Psychology with a minor in Literary and Cultural Studies, and a Post-Graduate Diploma in Interdisciplinary Studies and Research from FLAME University, India.

title: About Me
text:
Research interests
Public Opinion Dynamics, Behavioral Data, Networks, Community Psychology

title: About Me
text:
Fun fact
I’ve lived in the Middle East my whole life!

title: Blog Post Template
text:
Instructions
This document provides yaml header inforamtion you will need to replicate each week to submit your homework or other blog posts. Please observe the following conventions:

Save your own copy of this template as a blog post in the posts folder.
Edit the yaml header to change your author name
include a description that is reader friendly
update the category list to indicate what category is the blog post, the data used, the main packages or techniques, your name, or any thing else to make your document easy to find
edit as a normal qmd/rmd file



Code
x <- c(2,3,4,5)
mean(x)


[1] 3.5

title: Blog Post Template
text:
Rendering your post
When you click the Render button a document will be generated that includes both content and the output of embedded code.






Warning



Be sure that you have moved your *.qmd file into the posts folder BEFORE you render it, so that all files are stored in the correct location.








Important



Only render a single file - don’t try to render the whole website!








Pilot Student Blogs



We are piloting a workflow including individual student websites with direted and limited pull requests back to course blogs. Please let us know if you would like to participate.

title: Blog Post Template
text:
Reading in data files
The easiest data source to use - at least initially - is to choose something easily accessible, either from our _data folder provided, or from an online source that is publicly available.






Using Other Data



If you would like to use a source that you have access to and it is small enough and you don’t mind making it public, you can copy it into the _data file and include in your commit and pull request.








Using Private Data



If you would like to use a proprietary source of data, that should be possible using the same process outlined above. There may initially be a few issues. We hope to have this feature working smoothly soon!
